abstract.shortdesc: Steps for replacing a Ceph monitor node.

body.p: supports hosting the Ceph monitor service in the following configurations:
If you are hosting the Ceph monitor service on a controller node, then we have separate instructions for how to replace a controller node. See for more details.
If you configured your environment to have a dedicated resource for your Ceph monitor service, then these steps will assist you in replacing that node if that is needed.

ol.li: Log in to the lifecycle manager.

Edit your ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/servers.yml file to include the details of the replacement Ceph monitor node you are adding. Ensure that the role and server-group settings are the same as the Ceph monitor node you are replacing.
Commit the changes to git: git commit -a -m "Replacing node <name>"
Run the configuration processor: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml
Update your deployment directory: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml
Run the Cobbler deploy playbook to add your replacement node: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost cobbler-deploy.yml

Image your replacement node.
Obtain your server name in Cobbler: sudo cobbler system list
Image the node using this playbook, using the server name you obtained: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost bm-reimage.yml -e nodelist=<server_name>

Configure the operating system of the replacement node.
Obtain the hostname for your replacement node: cat /etc/hosts
Configure the operating system, using the hostname you obtained: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts osconfig-run.yml -limit <hostname_of_replacement_Ceph_monitor_node>

Stop the Ceph monitor service on the old monitor node using this playbook: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts ceph-stop.yml -limit <hostname_of_old_Ceph_monitor_node>
SSH to the old Ceph monitor node and remove it from the cluster using this command:ceph mon remove <old-mon-hostname> --cluster <cluster-name>

Log back into the lifecycle manager node and regenerate the hosts file on all the nodes in your environment and configure the services using this playbook:cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts site.yml --tags "generate_hosts_file" ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts site.yml -limit <hostname_of_replacement_Ceph_monitor_node>
Edit your ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/data/servers.yml file and remove the details of your old Ceph monitor node.
Commit the changes to git: git commit -a -m "Removing node <name>"
Run the configuration processor: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml
Update your deployment directory: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml

Remove the old Ceph monitor node from Cobbler.
Obtain the server name of your old Ceph monitor node with this command:sudo cobbler system list
Remove the server with this command:sudo cobbler system remove --name <old_server_name>
Regenerate the Ceph cluster configuration file on each of your Ceph clusters with this playbook:cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts ceph-reconfigure.yml
Ensure that the Ceph clients also receive the updated copy of the Ceph cluster configuration file:cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts ceph-client-prepare.yml
